lessons.title: Why learn about dyslexia
lessons.description: Discover the 3 key reasons to understand dyslexia and how it benefits everyone.

blocks.content: There are many reasons to learn about dyslexia. Here are just three of them.

items: Help someone with dyslexia without even realising they are dyslexic by producing more dyslexia-friendly documents
Help yourself by using some of the technologies and strategies for reading and writing that help people with dyslexia - they can improve everyone's writing
Produce documents that are easier to read for more people. Dyslexia-friendly documents are easier to read for everyone. Dyslexia-friendly documents are also easier to edit.

blocks.content: This page outlines 5 lessons you can learn. You can read them all at once, or schedule 15 minutes each day for five days to learn a new skill and integrate it into your practice.

lessons.title: About dyslexia and its immediate impacts
lessons.description: Understand dyslexia as a learning difficulty and experience what it feels like.

items: Dyslexia is a learning difficulty that makes it more challenging to decode letters into words during reading and to spell words during writing
Dyslexia is a hidden disability. This means that there is nothing that makes someone with dyslexia stand out in daily interactions
People are identified as having dyslexia at every stage of their educational journey as the need to rely on reading increases

Dyslexia is not linked to intelligence or any other quality. People with extremely high or low IQ can have dyslexia. People with dyslexia can understand the content of the text but they have to spend so much effort on decoding individual words, they have less left for overall meaning. Many successful academics have dyslexia
Dyslexia is a life-long condition, but it can be mitigated with training and technology.

blocks.content: Read the official definition of dyslexia from the Rose report:
'Dyslexia is a learning difficulty that primarily affects the skills involved in accurate and fluent word reading and spelling.'
What is dyslexia?, British Dyslexia Association (bdadyslexia.org.uk).
Try these two activities to see what it might feel like to read or write when someone is dyslexic:

items: Read a text in the mirror or in very tiny font
Write out a sentence by hand but write every a as @ and every e as 3.

blocks.content: What you will experience is:

items: Your reading and writing will slow down
You will make more errors
You will have to focus so much on individual words that you will struggle to make sense of the whole.

lessons.title: Structured, undistorted text is dyslexia friendly
lessons.description: Learn how structure helps everyone and 3 easy ways to format your documents.

blocks.content: Because dyslexia readers often read more slowly, they find it more difficult to skim or scan a text. Large chunks of undifferentiated text are very hard to process and may feel intimidating.
Three easy things you can do to make text more dyslexia friendly:

items: Bold key phrases in your paragraphs
Use numbers and bullets for lists
Labels sections with headings and mark them with heading styles.

blocks.content: Read readability.edutools.fyi.
Review one of your documents or websites to see how you could make it more dyslexia friendly.

lessons.title: Listening to text reduces processing overload
lessons.description: Reduce processing load by listening to text using modern TTS tools.

blocks.content: One way in which a person with dyslexia can reduce the processing overload is to listen to text.
Text to speech technology has improved greatly and is now available to everyone for free.
Read about how and why to listen to text at academicreading.edutools.fyi.
Try listening to text:

items: Open a document or email you wrote in Word Online or on your phone and choose Read Aloud
Open a webpage or a PDF in Microsoft Edge and choose Read Aloud.

blocks.content: This will help you in two ways:

items: You will have a better sense of how people with dyslexia and blind people experience text
You will be able to improve your own reading practices.

lessons.title: Dictating instead of writing reduces spelling overhead
lessons.description: Remove the stress of spelling by using free dictation tools.

blocks.content: Dictation can help reduce the stress of spelling for a person with dyslexia.
There are now many free tools for dictation.
Read about why and how to dictate at academicproductivity.edutools.fyi.

items: Open Word Online and try dictating a short piece of text
Think about what benefits and challenges a person with dyslexia will face when they use this method
Think about how you can use dictation to help you with your writing.

lessons.title: Visual aspects that make reading easier
lessons.description: Fonts, spacing, and colors that help (and what doesn't work).

blocks.content: Although dyslexia is not a visual difficulty, visual aspects of text can further slow down processing.
The same things that help readers with dyslexia improve the processing for everyone.
Things that help

items:
Do use
  1. larger font size
  2. increased line spacing
  3. shorter lines.

Do not use
  1. underline
  2. italics
  3. ALL CAPS.

blocks.content: Warm background colours (such as light cream) can also help with processing. But in general, it is best not to do this for documents as standard.
Things that do not help
Research has shown that two of the most commonly prescribed solutions for dyslexia do not work:

items: Dyslexia Font or other special fonts
Coloured overlays.

blocks.content: However, both may be preferred by people with dyslexia or others for a more comfortable reading experience.
Read readability.edutools.fyi.

items: Review one of your documents or websites to see how you could make it more dyslexia friendly.
Learn to enlarge documents you are reading
Change the background colour on your reader software to reduce visual stress.
